content: A farmer has a rectangular field that measures 300 meters by 500 meters. He wants to plant crops in rows spaced 1 meter apart. How many rows can he plant?

So the farmer has a rectangular field that's 300 meters by 500 meters, and he wants to plant crops in rows spaced 1 meter apart. He's asking how many rows he can plant.

First, I need to understand the layout of the field. A rectangular field has length and width, and in this case, the dimensions are 300 meters and 500 meters. So, depending on how he orientates his rows, the number of rows could be based on either dimension.

If he plants the rows along the 500-meter side, then the length of each row would be 500 meters, and the rows would be spaced 1 meter apart across the 300-meter width. So, the number of rows would be equal to the width divided by the row spacing.

Similarly, if he plants the rows along the 300-meter side, each row would be 300 meters long, and the rows would be spaced 1 meter apart across the 500-meter width, resulting in more rows.
